name: Marbled Teal
description: It has an overall brown to brownish-gray coloration with beige spotting. Its thin beak is black, and it has a small crest on its crown.
spread_note: Forms three separate populations—one breeds in the western Mediterranean and winters in North and West Africa, another breeds in the eastern Mediterranean and winters in Egypt, and a third breeds in western and southern Asia and winters in Iran, Pakistan, and India.
food_note: Parts of aquatic plants, aquatic invertebrates
image_alt: Marbled teal, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
reproduction: Females lay 7–12 eggs, incubating them alone for 25–27 days.
attractions: More closely related to pochards than other teals, it dives for food underwater. On wintering grounds, marbled teals form seasonal pairs that then seek a nesting site together.
projects_note: Due to habitat loss and degradation, its numbers have sharply declined, and it is listed as a vulnerable species on the IUCN Red List.
breeding: We have kept them since 1980 and have been breeding them since 2006.
